/wiki/Vukovar: Vukovar (Serbo-Croatian pronunciation: [ʋûkoʋaːr]; Serbian Cyrillic: Вуковар[Note 1]) is a city in eastern Croatia. It contains Croatia's largest river port, located at the confluence of the Vuka and the Danube. Vukovar is the seat of Vukovar-Syrmia County. The city's registered population was 26,468 in the 2011 census, with a total of 27,683 in the municipality.
/wiki/Lipova%C4%8Da,_Vukovar-Srijem_Coun: Lipovača  is a village in Croatia. It is connected by the D2 highway. Administratively, village is part of town of Vukovar, seat of Vukovar-Srijem County. Bobota Canal passes next to the village.
/wiki/Sotin: Sotin is a village in eastern Croatia, located a few kilometers southeast of Vukovar by the Danube. It is administratively part of the city of Vukovar, and its population is 782 (census 2011). The post code for Sotin is 32232 Sotin.
/wiki/Grabovo,_Croatia: Grabovo is a place south of Vukovar, Croatia. It consists of two hamlets, Ovčara and Jakobovac, in the north, which are administratively part of the city of Vukovar, and have a total population of 47, and an uninhabited section in the south which is administratively under the municipality of Tompojevci.
/wiki/Vinkovci: Vinkovci (pronounced [ʋîːŋkoːʋtsi]) is a city in Slavonia, in the Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. In the 2011 census, the total population of the city was 35,312, making it the largest town of the county. Surrounded by many large villages, it is a local transport hub, particularly because of its railways.
/wiki/Mirkovci: Mirkovci (Hungarian: Szegfalu, Serbian Cyrillic: Мирковци) is a village and suburb of the town of Vinkovci in eastern Croatia. It is geographically within the Syrmia region. The village is located immediately southeast of Vinkovci separated from the rest of the town by Vinkovci-Gunja railway. At the time of 2011 Census, the local population was 3,283.
/wiki/%C5%BDupanja: Županja (Croatian pronunciation: [ʒǔpaɲa]) is a town in eastern Slavonia, Croatia, located 254 km east of Zagreb. It is administratively part of the Vukovar-Srijem County. It is inhabited by 12,090 people (2011).
/wiki/Ilok: Ilok (Croatian pronunciation: [ilok]) is the easternmost town and municipality in northeastern Croatia. Located in the Syrmia region, it lies on a hill overlooking the Danube river, which forms the border with the Bačka region of Serbia. The population of the town of Ilok is 5,072, while the total municipality population is 6,767 (census 2011). The town is home to a Franciscan monastery and Ilok Castle, which is a popular day trip for domestic tourists.
/wiki/Bapska: Bapska is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Mohovo: Mohovo is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/%C5%A0arengrad: Šarengrad is a village in eastern Croatia. It is located along the Danube river and is administratively part of Croatian easternmost town of Ilok. Šarengrad is known for its landscape which is dominated by the river and picturesque houses and church tower next to it. Island of Šarengrad is an 9 km2 river island situated close to the village.
/wiki/Otok,_Vukovar-Srijem_County: Otok is a town in eastern Croatia, located 20 km south of Vinkovci, in eastern Slavonia. The population of the town of Otok is 6,343 (census 2011), with 4,694 residents in Otok itself and 1,649 in the nearby village of Komletinci. In the census of 2011, 99.31% of the population declared themselves Croats.
/wiki/Komletinci: Komletinci is a village in eastern Croatia located east of Otok. The population is 1,649 (census 2011).
/wiki/Andrija%C5%A1evci: Andrijaševci is a village and the eponymous municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. The 2011 census listed a total of 4,075 inhabitants in the municipality's two settlements:
/wiki/Rokovci: Rokovci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Babina_Greda: Babina Greda (Croatian pronunciation: [bâbina ɡrěːda]) is a village and a municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. The 2011 census listed 3,572 inhabitants in Babina Greda.
/wiki/Bogdanovci: Bogdanovci (Rusyn: Богдановци) is a village and municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. It is located a few kilometers south of Vukovar in eastern Slavonia. Bogdanovci is underdeveloped municipality which is statistically classified as the First Category Area of Special State Concern by the Government of Croatia.
/wiki/Petrovci,_Croatia: Petrovci (Rusyn: Петровци, Ukrainian: Петрівці) is a village in eastern Croatia.
/wiki/Svinjarevci: Svinjarevci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Borovo,_Croatia: Borovo (Serbian Cyrillic: Борово), (meaning "of the pines") locally known as Borovo selo (Borovo village, to distinguish it from relatively new nearby settlement of Borovo Naselje), is a village and an eponymous municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. It is situated on the river Danube on the border with Serbia. While being a municipality in its own right, Borovo is closely related with neighboring Vukovar, to which it is physically connected. It is a biggest settlement in Croatia in which Serbs of Croatia constitute ethnic majority.
/wiki/Bo%C5%A1njaci: Bošnjaci is a village and municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County in eastern Croatia. The 2011 census listed a total of 3,855 inhabitants, 98.8% of whom identified themselves as Croats.
/wiki/Cerna,_Croatia: Cerna is a village and a municipality in eastern Croatia, population 3,791 and 4,595, respectively (2011). It is located half-way between the cities of Vinkovci and Županja. 98.96% of the citizens are Croats. It is located on four rivers, Biđ, Bosut, Berava, Bitulja, Krajc channel and Kaluđer channel.
/wiki/%C5%A0i%C5%A1kovci: Šiškovci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Drenovci: Drenovci is a village and municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County in Croatia. According to the 2001 census, there are 7,424 inhabitants, 87.03% which are Croats. The municipality is part of Slavonia.
/wiki/%C4%90uri%C4%87i: Đurići is a village in eastern Croatia, located south of Drenovci.
/wiki/Posavski_Podgajci: Posavski Podgajci is a village in eastern Croatia located west of Drenovci, near the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The population is 1,255 (census 2011).
/wiki/Ra%C4%8Dinovci: Račinovci is a village in eastern Croatia located southeast of Drenovci, by the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia. The population is 700 (census 2011).
/wiki/Rajevo_Selo: Rajevo Selo is a village in eastern Croatia located west of Drenovci, near the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The population is 987 (census 2011).
/wiki/Gradi%C5%A1te,_Croatia: Gradište is a village and municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County in Croatia. According to the 2011 census, there are 2,773 inhabitants, 98.40% which are Croats.
/wiki/Gunja_(Croatia): Gunja is a village and municipality in Croatia.
/wiki/Ivankovo,_Croatia: Ivankovo is a village and a municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County, Slavonia in Croatia. It is located approximately 10 kilometres (6 miles) west of Vinkovci.
/wiki/Prkovci: Prkovci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Retkovci: Retkovci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Jarmina: Jarmina is a village and municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County in Croatia.
/wiki/Borinci: Borinci is a hamlet in Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia. It is administratively located in the of Town of Vinkovci as a part of settlement of Vinkovci itself.
/wiki/Lovas,_Croatia: Lovas is a village and seat of municipality in the Vukovar-Syrmia County of eastern Croatia, located on the slopes of Fruška Gora, a few kilometers south of the main road connecting Vukovar with Ilok. Lovas has a population of 1,214 (2011), and its municipality also includes the smaller village of Opatovac (pop. 345 in 2011) which is located to the north, at the Danube. Lovas is underdeveloped municipality which is statistically classified as the First Category Area of Special State Concern by the Government of Croatia.
/wiki/Opatovac,_Vukovar-Srijem_County: Opatovac  (pronounced [opǎːtovat͡s]) is a village in Croatia. It is connected by the D2 highway.
/wiki/Marku%C5%A1ica: Markušica (Hungarian: Márkusfalva, Serbian Cyrillic: Маркушица) is a village and a municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia.
/wiki/Gabo%C5%A1: Gaboš (Serbian Cyrillic: Габош) is a village in Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia, population 516.
/wiki/Karad%C5%BEi%C4%87evo: Karadžićevo (Serbian Cyrillic: Караџићево) is a village in Croatia, municipality Markušica, Vukovar-Srijem County.
/wiki/Ostrovo,_Croatia: Ostrovo (Serbian Cyrillic: Острово) is a village in Croatia, municipality Markušica, Vukovar-Srijem County.
/wiki/Podrinje: Podrinje (Cyrillic: Подриње) is the Slavic name of the Drina river basin, known in English as the Drina Valley, located in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia.
/wiki/Negoslavci: Negoslavci (Serbian Cyrillic: Негославци) is a village and a municipality in Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia.
/wiki/Nijemci: Nijemci is a village and a municipality in the Vukovar-Srijem County in Croatia.
/wiki/Ap%C5%A1evci: Apševci  is a village in Croatia.
/wiki/Banovci,_Vukovar-Srijem_County:
Banovci (German: Schider Banovci, Serbian Cyrillic: Бановци or Шидски Бановци) is a village in eastern Croatia, 7 kilometers away from the Serbian border.
It is connected to surrounding areas by the D46 road and Zagreb-Belgrade Railway. The village is 116 km away from Belgrade (Serbia), 158 km from Sarajevo (Bosnia), 249 km from Zagreb (Croatia) and 257 km from Budapest (Hungary).
/wiki/Donje_Novo_Selo,_Serbia: Donje Novo Selo is a village in the municipality of Bujanovac, Serbia. According to the 2002 census, the town has a population of 120 people.
/wiki/%C4%90eletovci:
Đeletovci is a village in the municipality of Nijemci within the Vukovar-Srijem County, Croatia. It had a population of 511 people in the 2011 census.
The village is located on the Zagreb-Belgrade Railway.
/wiki/Lipovac,_Croatia: Lipovac is a village located in Srijem, eastern Croatia, at the border with Serbia. It is administratively part of the Nijemci municipality. The population is 814 (census 2011).
/wiki/Podgra%C4%91e,_Vukovar-Srijem_Coun: Podgrađe is a village in eastern Croatia.
/wiki/Vinkova%C4%8Dki_Banovci: Vinkovački Banovci (Serbian Cyrillic: Винковачки Бановци) is a village in Croatia in the region of Syrmia. It is inhabited mostly members of the Serbian minority. The first word of its name is an adjective for Vinkovci that distinguishes it from the adjacent village of Banovci.
